title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of PCR (polymerase chain reaction) testing in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To amplify genetic information to large enough quantities that it can be readily observed

options.label: B
options.text: To identify and fight foreign substances, like viruses

options.label: C
options.text: To detect IgM antibodies, the type that's first produced in response to a new infection

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the genetic material used by a virus

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following viruses uses DNA as its genetic material?
What is the process called when viral RNA is converted to a strand of complementary DNA before running the PCR?
What is the primary function of immunoassays in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of a virus's genetic material in a sample

options.label: B
options.text: To detect IgM antibodies, the type that's first produced in response to a new infection

options.label: C
options.text: To tap into the immune system's memory of the virus

options.label: D
options.text: To identify and fight foreign substances, like viruses

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following antibodies is produced in response to a new infection and can indicate a recent infection?
What is the potential use of blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: To treat people who are currently fighting the virus

options.label: D
options.text: To study the virus's genetic material

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of making a strand of complementary DNA from viral RNA before running the PCR?
What is the primary advantage of using self-contained testing devices that relay results within one hour?
What is the potential benefit of using digital PCR to quantify individual pieces of target DNA?

options.label: B
options.text: It can reduce the time it takes to run the PCR

options.label: C
options.text: It can increase the amount of genetic information that can be observed

options.label: D
options.text: It can reduce the cost of the PCR

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of deploying viral testing early in the course of an outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: It can save millions of lives

options.label: B
options.text: It can reduce the spread of the virus

options.label: C
options.text: It can increase the number of cases

title: What is a coronavirus? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the virus that causes the disease COVID-19?

options.label: B
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person

options.label: C
options.text: Through droplets containing the virus that enter the nose or mouth

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the enzyme that coronaviruses have to counteract replication errors?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes mutations in the virus

options.label: B
options.text: It checks for replication errors and corrects mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: It speeds up the mutation rate of the virus

options.label: D
options.text: It slows down the replication rate of the virus

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the virus to mutate quickly and evade the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: It makes our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines more effective

options.label: D
options.text: It makes it easier for the virus to jump from animals to humans

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus mutates quickly and new strains pop up constantly

options.label: B
options.text: The virus is highly contagious and spreads easily

options.label: C
options.text: The virus causes severe illnesses and has a high mortality rate

options.label: D
options.text: The virus is difficult to detect and diagnose

options.label: B
options.text: A slower mutation rate makes it harder for the virus to evade the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: A faster mutation rate makes it easier for the virus to evade the immune system

multiple-choice.question: How do coronaviruses infect host cells?

options.label: B
options.text: By hijacking the host cell's machinery to replicate their own genes

options.label: C
options.text: By entering the host cell through a process called endocytosis

options.label: D
options.text: By attaching to the host cell surface and entering through a process called phagocytosis

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists say that a new coronavirus jumping to humans is inevitable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we have not focused on treating coronaviruses in the past

options.label: B
options.text: Because we have not developed effective treatments or vaccines for coronaviruses

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are encroaching on other animals' habitats and increasing the risk of transmission

options.label: D
options.text: Because coronaviruses are highly contagious and spread easily

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why coronaviruses are more stable than other RNA viruses?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a slow mutation rate that is faster than other RNA viruses

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a proofreading mechanism that prevents mutations

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a slower mutation rate than other RNA viruses
